Unlensed events

:math:`z_s`: source redshift, :math:`theta`: GWs parameters, :math:`Theta`: step function, :math:`rho(z_s,theta)`: network optimal SNR, :math:`rho_{th}`: threshold SNR, :math:`R_o^U(z_s)`: normalized merger-rate distribution, :math:`mathcal{N}^U`: normalizing factor, :math:`P`: prior distribution.

BBH/BNS merger rate density

  • Check for all available models here.

  • LeR default Merger rate follows WIERDA et al. 2021.

  • It is a functional fit to the population I/II star merger-rate density normalized to the local merger- rate density following Oguri (2018).

  • This model follows from the M10 model to the Belczynski et al. (2017), which is arrived from Madau & Dickinson (2014) with the inclusion of the metallicity dependence of the star formation rate, which is bassically the effect related to pair-instability supernova (PSN) and pair-instability pulsation supernova (PPSN).

\begin{equation} \mathcal{R}_m(z_s) = \frac{\mathcal{R}_O(b_4+1)e^{b_2 z_s}}{b_4+e^{b_3 z_s}} \text{Gpc}^{-3}\text{yr}^{-1} \tag{1} \end{equation} * \(z_s\): redshift of source * \(\mathcal{R}\): local mergerrate. \(\mathcal{R}=23.9^{+14.3}_{-8.6}\text{Gpc}^{-3}\text{yr}^{-1}=23.9^{+14.3}_{-8.6} \times 10^{-9}\text{Mpc}^{-3}\text{yr}^{-1}\) * fitting parameters: \(b_2=1.6\), \(b_3=2.1\), \(b_4=30\)

Detectable Unlensed events’ rate in a year

  • Detectable unlensed events’ rate in a year is given by the following equation.

\begin{equation} R_U = \mathcal{N}^U\int dz_s R_o^U(z_s)\left\{\Theta[\rho(z_s,\theta)-\rho_{th}] P(\theta) d\theta \right\} \tag{2} \end{equation}

  • SNR operator \(\Theta[\rho(z_s,\theta)-\rho_{th}]\) is a step function. \(\rho_{th}\) is the threshold SNR.

  • \(P(\theta)\) is considered to normalized.

  • Pdet (probability of detection) can be used instead of SNR operator. It allows smoother transition from detectable to non-detectable events at the SNR threshold.

  • \(R_o^U(z_s)\) is the normalized merger-rate distribution.

  • \(\theta \in\) {\(m_1\):mass1, \(m_2\):mass2, \(D_l\):luminosity-distance, \(\iota\):inclination-angle, \(\psi\):polarization, \(ra\):right-ascension,\(dec\):declination,\(\phi_c\):phase-of-coalescene,\(t_c\):time-of-coalescene}.

  • \(D_l\) is derived from \(z_s\).

BBH/BNS merger rate at source redshift \(z_s\) (in small dz)

  • \(R(z_s)\) is the merger rate at source redshift \(z_s\) in source frame.

\begin{equation} R(z_s) = \frac{\mathcal{R}_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tag{3} \end{equation}

  • \((1+z)\) factor in the denominator is due to the time dilation effect. It basically change from detector frame to source frame.

  • co-moving volume : \(\frac{dV_c}{dz_s}\).

  • sampling of \(z_s\) is done through rejection sampling with the merger rate formula given above.

  • \(\mathcal{N}^U\) is the normalizing factor of merger rate distribution wrt \(z_s\).

\begin{equation} \mathcal{N}^U = \int_{z_{min}}^{z_{max}} dz_s \frac{R_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tag{4} \end{equation}

  • \(R_o^U(z_s)\) is the normalized merger-rate distribution.

\begin{equation} R_o^U(z_s)= \frac{1}{\mathcal{N}^U}\frac{R_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tag{5} \end{equation}

[0,10]

PowerLaw+PEAK model

[\(m_{min}\),\(m_{max}\)]

\(ra\)

radian

Uniform

[0,\(2\pi\)]

\(dec\)

radian

cosine

[\(-\pi/2\),\(\pi/2\)]

\(\iota\)

radian

sine

[\(0\),\(\pi\)]

\(\psi\)

radian

Uniform

[\(0\),\(\pi\)]

\(\phi_c\)

radian

Uniform

[\(0\),\(2\pi\)]

\(t_c\)

sec

Uniform(one year)

[\(t_{min}\),\(t_{max}\)]

Montecarlo integration

  • With step function.

\begin{equation} \begin{split} R_U &= \mathcal{N}^U \left< \Theta[\rho(z_s,\theta)-\rho_{th}]\right>_{z_s,\theta \in Sampled[z_s,\theta]} \\ &= \frac{\mathcal{N}^U}{N} \sum_i \Theta[\rho(z_s^i,\theta_i)-\rho_{th}] \end{split} \tag{6} \end{equation}

  • With Pdet.

\begin{equation} \begin{split} R_U &= \mathcal{N}^U \left< P_{det}(z_s,\theta)\right>_{z_s,\theta \in Sampled[z_s,\theta]} \\ &= \frac{\mathcal{N}^U}{N} \sum_i P_{det}(z_s^i,\theta_i) \end{split} \tag{7} \end{equation}

SNR calculation methods

  • SNR: optimal network signal-to-noise ratio

Inner-product

  • Refer to bilby.gw.detector.get_network_optimal_snr function.

  • Given the power spectral density \(S_n(f)\) of the detector, the optimal network signal-to-noise ratio is given by

\begin{equation} \rho = \sqrt{4\int_0^\infty \frac{|\tilde{h}(f)|^2}{S_n(f)}df} \tag{8} \end{equation}

  • \(\tilde{h}(f)\) is the waveform in the frequency domain.

\begin{equation} |\tilde{h}(f)|^2 = \left| \tilde{h}_+(f) F_+ + \tilde{h}_\times(f) F_\times \right|^2 \tag{9} \end{equation}

  • \(F_+\) and \(F_\times\) are the antenna pattern functions. It depends on the source location, detector orientation and polarization angle.

  • \(\tilde{h}_+\) and \(\tilde{h}_\times\) are the two polarizations of the waveform in the frequency domain.

Interpolation

  • Refer to gwsnr package.

  • Simple interpretation of SNR is from https://arxiv.org/pdf/1909.06296.pdf Equation D1 and 3.4 .

\begin{equation} \begin{split} \rho &= \sqrt{4\int_0^\infty \frac{|h(f)|^2}{S_n(f)}df} \\ &= \left( \frac{1 Mpc}{D_{eff}} \right)\mathcal{A}_{1Mpc} \sqrt{ 4\int_0^\infty \frac{f^{-7/3}}{S_n(f)}df } \end{split} \tag{10} \end{equation}

  • Defining Half-sacaled SNR:

\begin{equation} \begin{split} \rho_{1/2} &= \left( \frac{D_{eff}}{1 Mpc} \right)\mathcal{A}_{1Mpc}^{-1} \times \rho \\ &= \sqrt{ 4\int_0^\infty \frac{f^{-7/3}}{S_n(f)}df } \end{split} \tag{11} \end{equation}

  • Interpolation of \(\rho_{1/2}\) from the pre-calculated SNR table.

  • Works with spinless waveform only.

  • Tested with TaylorF2 and IMRPhenomD waveforms.

Pdet

  • LeR can use Pdet instead of SNR.

  • Pdet is the probability of detection.

  • SNR is taken to a gaussian distribution with mean \(\rho\) optimal and standard deviation \(\sigma\) of 1.

  • Pdet is the probability of SNR being greater than the threshold SNR \(\rho_{th}\). So its a cumulative distribution function of the gaussian distribution.

Advantages of Pdet over SNR: * Pdet is a smooth function of SNR. So it allows smoother transition from detectable to non-detectable events at the SNR threshold. * Pdet is a probability. So it is always between 0 and 1. So it is easy to interpret
